page.title: 08BRECON BEACONS
page.content: The area is known as the Brecon Beacons, in Welsh it is called Bannau Brycheiniog. The peaks are formed from Old Red Sandstone. The highest peak is Pen-y-Fan 886m. In the 1950s the 10 finest large areas of countryside were designated National Parks, to conserve their beauty and special character. The area is looked after by the Brecon Beacons National Park. The National Park officers advise farmers on developing their land and control all planning applications. They also provide an information service for tourists at the Mountain Centre west of the village of Libanus.
